qas.question: The state with the lowest possible energy in quantum mechanics defines what ?
A vacuum state with no matter particles or photons is called what?
why is a QED vacuum impossible to achieve ?

answers.text: impossible to eliminate all the blackbody photons

plausible_answers.text: the state (that is, the solution to the equations of the theory) with the lowest possible energy

qas.question: What are blackbody photons in quantum mechanics?
What do blackbody photons with no matter particles or photons form?

plausible_answers.text: impossible to eliminate all the blackbody photons

qas.question: Why is a blackbody field impossible to achieve?
What would you need to remove to create a blackbody field?
What is a blackbody photon referred to in quantum mechanics?

context: In quantum mechanics and quantum field theory, the <a0_0>vacuum<a0_0/> is defined as <b4_0>the state (that is, the solution to the equations of the theory) with the lowest possible energy<b4_0/> (the ground state of the Hilbert space). In quantum electrodynamics this vacuum is referred to as <b8_0>'QED vacuum'<b8_0/> to distinguish it from the <a3_0>vacuum of quantum chromodynamics,<a3_0/> denoted as QCD vacuum. <a1_0><b5_0>QED<a1_0/> vacuum<b5_0/> is a state with no matter particles (hence the name), and also no photons. As described above, this state is impossible to achieve experimentally. (Even if <b7_0>every matter particle<b7_0/> could somehow be removed from a volume, it would be <a2_0><b6_0>impossible to eliminate all the blackbody photons<b6_0/><a2_0/>.) Nonetheless, it provides a good model for realizable vacuum, and agrees with a number of experimental observations as described next.
